notes.title: Welcome to OME Medicine Notes
notes.html:
Welcome to OME Medicine Notes

This is a sample vault to demonstrate the Obsidian Publisher features.

Features Demonstrated

  • Heart Failure - A complete cardiology note
  • Asthma - A pulmonology note with callouts
  • Wikilinks and navigation
  • Full-text search (try searching for "BNP" or "albuterol")
  • Dark/light mode toggle
  • Export to PDF or Markdown

Quick Stats

Specialty Notes Count
Cardiology 1
Pulmonology 1

Tags

Check out notes tagged with #cardiology or #pulmonology.

TIP: > Use the sidebar to navigate through the folder structure, or use **Cmd/Ctrl + K** to search!
notes.content:
# Welcome to OME Medicine Notes

This is a sample vault to demonstrate the **Obsidian Publisher** features.

## Features Demonstrated

- [[Heart Failure]] - A complete cardiology note
- [[Asthma]] - A pulmonology note with callouts
- Wikilinks and navigation
- Full-text search (try searching for "BNP" or "albuterol")

- Export to PDF or Markdown

| Pulmonology | 1 |

## Tags

notes.title: Asthma
notes.html:
Asthma

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperresponsiveness, and underlying inflammation.

Pathophysiology

The key features are:

  1. Chronic airway inflammation - Eosinophils, mast cells, T-lymphocytes
  2. Bronchial hyperreactivity - Exaggerated bronchoconstriction
  3. Reversible airflow obstruction - Responds to bronchodilators

Clinical Features

Symptoms

  • Wheezing (expiratory)
  • Shortness of breath
  • Chest tightness
  • Cough (often nocturnal)
TIP: > Symptoms often worse at night or early morning, and triggered by:
- Allergens (dust, pollen, pets) - Exercise - Cold air - Respiratory infections

Physical Exam

  • Wheezing on auscultation
  • Prolonged expiratory phase
  • Use of accessory muscles (severe)
  • Nasal polyps (in aspirin-exacerbated disease)

Diagnosis

Spirometry (Key Test)

Parameter Findings
FEV1 Reduced
FVC Normal or reduced
FEV1/FVC <0.70 (obstructive pattern)
Bronchodilator response ≥12% AND ≥200mL improvement

Other Tests

  • Peak flow variability >20%
  • Methacholine challenge (if spirometry normal)
  • Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) - elevated in eosinophilic asthma
  • Allergy testing

Classification by Severity

Intermittent:
  - Symptoms ≤2 days/week
  - Night symptoms ≤2x/month
  - FEV1 ≥80% predicted

Mild Persistent:
  - Symptoms >2 days/week (not daily)
  - Night symptoms 3-4x/month
  - FEV1 ≥80% predicted

Moderate Persistent:
  - Daily symptoms
  - Night symptoms >1x/week
  - FEV1 60-80% predicted

Severe Persistent:
  - Continuous symptoms
  - Frequent night symptoms
  - FEV1 <60% predicted

Treatment

Quick-Relief Medications

IMPORTANT: > **SABA** (Short-Acting Beta-Agonist) is the first-line rescue medication
- Albuterol (salbutamol) - Levalbuterol

Controller Medications (Stepwise Approach)

Step 1: SABA as needed
Step 2: Low-dose ICS
Step 3: Low-dose ICS + LABA
Step 4: Medium-dose ICS + LABA
Step 5: High-dose ICS + LABA ± add-on therapy
Step 6: Oral corticosteroids + biologics

Biologics for Severe Asthma

  • Omalizumab - Anti-IgE (allergic asthma)
  • Mepolizumab/Benralizumab - Anti-IL-5 (eosinophilic)
  • Dupilumab - Anti-IL-4/13

Acute Exacerbation Management

CAUTION: > Signs of life-threatening asthma:
- Silent chest - Cyanosis - Altered consciousness - SpO2 <92%

Management algorithm:

  1. Oxygen - Target SpO2 94-98%
  2. SABA nebulizer - q20min x3, then as needed
  3. Ipratropium - Add in severe exacerbations
  4. Corticosteroids - Prednisone 40-60mg PO (or IV methylpred)
  5. Consider: Magnesium sulfate IV, epinephrine

Related Notes

  • Back to: Heart Failure for cardiac causes of dyspnea
  • Welcome for vault overview

#pulmonology #asthma #chronic
notes.content:
# Asthma

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperresponsiveness, and underlying inflammation.

## Pathophysiology

The key features are:

1. **Chronic airway inflammation** - Eosinophils, mast cells, T-lymphocytes
2. **Bronchial hyperreactivity** - Exaggerated bronchoconstriction
3. **Reversible airflow obstruction** - Responds to bronchodilators

## Clinical Features

### Symptoms
- Wheezing (expiratory)
- Shortness of breath
- Chest tightness
- Cough (often nocturnal)

> [!TIP]
> Symptoms often worse at night or early morning, and triggered by:
> - Allergens (dust, pollen, pets)
> - Exercise
> - Cold air
> - Respiratory infections

### Physical Exam
- Wheezing on auscultation
- Prolonged expiratory phase
- Use of accessory muscles (severe)
- Nasal polyps (in aspirin-exacerbated disease)

## Diagnosis

### Spirometry (Key Test)
| Parameter | Findings |
|-----------|----------|
| FEV1 | Reduced |
| FVC | Normal or reduced |
| FEV1/FVC | <0.70 (obstructive pattern) |
| Bronchodilator response | ≥12% AND ≥200mL improvement |

### Other Tests
- Peak flow variability >20%
- Methacholine challenge (if spirometry normal)
- Exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) - elevated in eosinophilic asthma
- Allergy testing

## Classification by Severity

```
Intermittent:
  - Symptoms ≤2 days/week
  - Night symptoms ≤2x/month
  - FEV1 ≥80% predicted

Mild Persistent:
  - Symptoms >2 days/week (not daily)
  - Night symptoms 3-4x/month
  - FEV1 ≥80% predicted

Moderate Persistent:
  - Daily symptoms
  - Night symptoms >1x/week
  - FEV1 60-80% predicted

Severe Persistent:
  - Continuous symptoms
  - Frequent night symptoms
  - FEV1 <60% predicted
```

## Treatment

### Quick-Relief Medications

> [!IMPORTANT]
> **SABA** (Short-Acting Beta-Agonist) is the first-line rescue medication
> - Albuterol (salbutamol)
> - Levalbuterol

### Controller Medications (Stepwise Approach)

**Step 1**: SABA as needed
**Step 2**: Low-dose ICS
**Step 3**: Low-dose ICS + LABA
**Step 4**: Medium-dose ICS + LABA
**Step 5**: High-dose ICS + LABA ± add-on therapy
**Step 6**: Oral corticosteroids + biologics

### Biologics for Severe Asthma
- **Omalizumab** - Anti-IgE (allergic asthma)
- **Mepolizumab/Benralizumab** - Anti-IL-5 (eosinophilic)
- **Dupilumab** - Anti-IL-4/13

## Acute Exacerbation Management

> [!CAUTION]
> Signs of life-threatening asthma:
> - Silent chest
> - Cyanosis
> - Altered consciousness
> - SpO2 <92%

Management algorithm:
1. **Oxygen** - Target SpO2 94-98%
2. **SABA nebulizer** - q20min x3, then as needed
3. **Ipratropium** - Add in severe exacerbations
4. **Corticosteroids** - Prednisone 40-60mg PO (or IV methylpred)
5. **Consider**: Magnesium sulfate IV, epinephrine

## Related Notes
- Back to: [[Heart Failure]] for cardiac causes of dyspnea
- [[Welcome]] for vault overview

---

#pulmonology #asthma #chronic

notes.title: Heart Failure
notes.html:
Heart Failure

Heart failure (HF) is a clinical syndrome caused by structural or functional cardiac abnormalities resulting in reduced cardiac output and/or elevated intracardiac pressures.

Classification

By Ejection Fraction

  • HFrEF (Reduced EF): EF ≤40%
  • HFmrEF (Mildly Reduced EF): EF 41-49%
  • HFpEF (Preserved EF): EF ≥50%

By Timing

  • Acute HF: Rapid onset of symptoms
  • Chronic HF: Progressive, long-term condition

Etiology

  1. Ischemic heart disease (most common)
  2. Hypertension
  3. Valvular disease
  4. Cardiomyopathies
  5. Arrhythmias

Clinical Features

IMPORTANT: > Remember the classic presentation:
- **Left-sided failure**: Dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, pulmonary edema - **Right-sided failure**: JVD, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly

Symptoms

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea (need to sleep with pillows)
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND)
  • Fatigue
  • Lower extremity edema

Signs

  • Elevated JVP
  • S3 gallop (volume overload)
  • Pulmonary crackles
  • Peripheral edema
  • Hepatomegaly

Diagnosis

Labs

Test Finding in HF
BNP >100 pg/mL suggests HF
NT-proBNP >300 pg/mL in acute setting
Troponin May be elevated in acute HF

Imaging

  • Echocardiogram: Gold standard for EF assessment
  • CXR: Cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion
  • Cardiac MRI: For detailed structural assessment

Treatment

Acute Management

1. Position: Sit patient upright
2. Oxygen: Target SpO2 ≥94%
3. Diuretics: IV furosemide 40-80mg
4. Vasodilators: Nitrates if BP adequate
5. Consider: Inotropes if cardiogenic shock

Chronic HFrEF (Four Pillars of Therapy)

NOTE: > Guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) includes four classes of drugs that reduce mortality:
  1. ACE inhibitor/ARB/ARNI - Start low, titrate up
  2. Beta-blocker (carvedilol, metoprolol succinate, bisoprolol)
  3. Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (spironolactone, eplerenone)
  4. SGLT2 inhibitor (dapagliflozin, empagliflozin)

Device Therapy

  • ICD: For EF ≤35% after 3 months of GDMT
  • CRT: For EF ≤35% + LBBB + QRS ≥150ms

Prognosis

WARNING: > 5-year mortality is approximately 50% after diagnosis. Early GDMT initiation is crucial!

Related Notes

  • See also: Asthma for pulmonary differential

#cardiology #HF #acute
notes.content:
# Heart Failure

Heart failure (HF) is a clinical syndrome caused by structural or functional cardiac abnormalities resulting in reduced cardiac output and/or elevated intracardiac pressures.

## Classification

### By Ejection Fraction
- **HFrEF** (Reduced EF): EF ≤40%
- **HFmrEF** (Mildly Reduced EF): EF 41-49%
- **HFpEF** (Preserved EF): EF ≥50%

### By Timing
- **Acute HF**: Rapid onset of symptoms
- **Chronic HF**: Progressive, long-term condition

## Etiology

1. **Ischemic heart disease** (most common)
2. Hypertension
3. Valvular disease
4. Cardiomyopathies
5. Arrhythmias

## Clinical Features

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Remember the classic presentation:
> - **Left-sided failure**: Dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, pulmonary edema
> - **Right-sided failure**: JVD, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly

### Symptoms
- Dyspnea on exertion
- Orthopnea (need to sleep with pillows)
- Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND)
- Fatigue
- Lower extremity edema

### Signs
- Elevated JVP
- S3 gallop (volume overload)
- Pulmonary crackles
- Peripheral edema
- Hepatomegaly

## Diagnosis

### Labs
| Test | Finding in HF |
|------|---------------|
| BNP | >100 pg/mL suggests HF |
| NT-proBNP | >300 pg/mL in acute setting |
| Troponin | May be elevated in acute HF |

### Imaging
- **Echocardiogram**: Gold standard for EF assessment
- **CXR**: Cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion
- **Cardiac MRI**: For detailed structural assessment

## Treatment

### Acute Management
```
1. Position: Sit patient upright
2. Oxygen: Target SpO2 ≥94%
3. Diuretics: IV furosemide 40-80mg
4. Vasodilators: Nitrates if BP adequate
5. Consider: Inotropes if cardiogenic shock
```

### Chronic HFrEF (Four Pillars of Therapy)

> [!NOTE]
> Guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) includes four classes of drugs that reduce mortality:

1. **ACE inhibitor/ARB/ARNI** - Start low, titrate up
2. **Beta-blocker** (carvedilol, metoprolol succinate, bisoprolol)
3. **Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist** (spironolactone, eplerenone)
4. **SGLT2 inhibitor** (dapagliflozin, empagliflozin)

### Device Therapy
- **ICD**: For EF ≤35% after 3 months of GDMT
- **CRT**: For EF ≤35% + LBBB + QRS ≥150ms

## Prognosis

> [!WARNING]
> 5-year mortality is approximately 50% after diagnosis. Early GDMT initiation is crucial!

## Related Notes
- See also: [[Asthma]] for pulmonary differential

---

#cardiology #HF #acute
